summary.seg: This manuscript is formed of two parts: A collection of letters by Theophylact of Ohrid and a Church History.

Part I contains the collection of letters by Theophylact, bishop of Ohrid (ca.1050-after 1126), who was a pupil of the famous Byzantine polymath Michael Psellos and deacon of Hagia Sophia. It was copied around the middle of the 16th century by the scribe Manuel Provataris (also known as Emmanuel Graecus). Born in Crete, Provataris was Scriptor at the Vatican Library from 1546-1571.

Part II contains a Church History ( Historia Ecclesiastica). Traditionally attributed to Gelasius of Cyzicus on the basis of a mention by patriarch Photius in his Bibliotheca (see Hansen (2002), pp. ix-xii), this work consists mainly of a collection of Acts of the Nicene Council (325 CE). This part of the manuscript was copied from Torino, Biblioteca Nazionale Universitaria, B.I.1 , a codex which was owned by Cardinal Domenico Grimani (see A. Diller, H.D. Saffrey, L.G. Westerink, Bibliotheca Graeca Manuscripta Cardinalis Dominici Grimani (1461-1523) (Venice, 2003), no. 391 p. 165) and was brought with his collection to the monastery of S. Antonio di Castello in Venice after his death in 1523 ( Hansen (2002), p. xxv). Trinity MS B.3.18 was used as the exemplar for the copy of the text in Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, 788 , which was written between the second half of the 16th century and the beginning of the 17th, and for Città del Vaticano, Biblioteca Apostolica Varicana, Reg. gr. 73 ( Hansen 2002, p. xxvi).

supportDesc.foliation:
The leaves are foliated in brown ink from 1 to 144; this foliation jumps from f. 50 to 52, therefore, starting from 52, it has been erased with a line and corrected in pencil. The pencil foliation goes from 51 to 144 (this last, blank leaf, had not been originally numbered). At the beginning, used as endleaves, there are:
a parchment strip from a manuscript (f. [i])
a blank paper strip (f. [ii])
two paper stubs (ff. [iii]-[iv], only the rectos imaged)
two paper leaves from a printed book (ff. [v]-[vi])
a blank paper leaf (f. [vii]) . At the end, used as endleaves, there are:
two paper leaves from a printed book (ff. [viii]-[ix])
a parchment strip from a manuscript (f. [x]) . [i]-[vii] + 1-144 + [viii]-[x]

condition.p: The manuscript is in good condition. The endleaves are stained.

additions.p: On the left pastedown is written the shelfmark B.3.18, in brown ink; a previous one, B.4.14, has been struck through.

In the upper margin of f. [v] recto there is a note in Latin, in brown ink, indicating the manuscript's contents: Theophylacti Epistulae pag. 1 | Historia Concilii Nicaeni pag. 41. Below are written the present shelfmark, B.3.18, and a previous one, B.4.14 (erased with a stroke).
A note in Latin is written in the upper margin of f. [viii] recto.

binding.p: Western full leather cover over pasteboards. Blind-tooled four-fillets frame motif on both boards. On the spine are pasted three paper labels with the shelfmark. The edges are coloured in red, on the fore-edge is written the number 18. 325 230 45
binding.condition: Rebacked. There are scratches on the right cover.

accMat.p:
The following were bound into the manuscript as endleaves, at the beginning:
f. [i], a parchment strip from a manuscript (a gloss on the Gospels, 13th c., see James 1900, p. 118), bound upside down
f. [ii], a blank paper strip
ff. [iii]-[iv], two paper stubs (only rectos imaged), with a few incomplete words in Greek written on, now upside down
ff. [v]-[vi], two paper leaves from Calepinus' Latin Lexicon, with handwritten marginal notes in Greek; the printed pages have been bound upside down
f. [vii] a blank paper leaf And at the end:
ff. [viii]-[ix], two paper leaves from Calepinus' Latin Lexicon, with handwritten marginal notes in Greek; the printed pages have been bound upside down
f. [x], a parchment strip from a manuscript (from a law manuscript, 13th c., see James 1900, p. 118).

history.provenance: The manuscript was owned by Nevile, Thomas, -1615 Thomas Nevile (ca. 1548-1615) , Master of Trinity College and Dean of Canterbury; in the list of manuscripts donated to the College by Thomas Nevile contained in the Trinity College Memoriale (MS Trinity R.17.8), made in about 1614, it can be identified with the entry Theophilacti epistolae graece. In the lower margin of f. 1r is pasted a paper label which indicates Nevile's donation: Ex dono ornatissimi viri Thomae | Nevile Decani Cantuariensis, et | Collegii Trinitatis Praefecti.
history.acquisition: The manuscript was donated to the Library by Thomas Nevile (ca. 1548-1615) Nevile, Thomas, -1615 , in the years 1611-1612 (for the date of the donation see P. Gaskell, Trinity College Library: the first 150 years. The Sandars Lectures 1978-9 (Cambridge, 1980), p. 81). On the left pastedown is pasted the Trinity College bookplate. Stamps of Trinity College Library are present on ff. 1r and 143r.

recordHist.source: Description (2021) draws partly on M.R. James, The Western Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College Cambridge (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1900) vol. 1, p. 118.

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.

monogr.title: The western manuscripts in the library of Trinity College: a descriptive catalogue

series.title: Corpus fontium historiae Byzantinae; Series Thessalonicensis
Griechischen christlichen Schriftsteller der ersten Jahrhunderte (1995)

msContents.summary: This part of the manuscript contains a collection of 60 letters by Theophylactus of Ohrid, copied from MS Città del Vaticano, Biblioteca Apostolica Vaticana, gr. 509 ( Gautier 1986, pp. 22-23).

msItem.author: Theophylactus, Archbishop of Ochrida (c. 1050-c.1108)
msItem.title: Epistles
msItem.rubric: f. 1r Ἐπιστολαὶ τοῦ μακαριωτάτου ἐπισκόπου Βουλγαρίας κυροῦ Θεοφυλάκτου

msItem.title: Epistle 4 (Gautier)
msItem.incipit: f. 1r Δέσποινά μου ἁγία πολλοῖς μὲν ἐν τοῖς λυπηροῖς
msItem.explicit: f. 2r l. 21 τερπνὸν καὶ δεκτὸν θυμίαμα.

msItem.title: Epistle 5 (Gautier)
msItem.incipit: f. 2r Ἅγιέ μου αὐθέντα, εἰ μὲν καὶ τὸ σὸν ὕψος
msItem.explicit: f. 3r l. 4 τοῖς δ’ ἀνασχομένοις τυχὸν δυσκλεές.

msItem.title: Epistle 6 (Gautier)
msItem.incipit: f. 3r l. 5 Ὅδ’ ἀνὴρ οὐκέτ’ αὐτός
msItem.explicit: f. 3v l. 15 τὸ κόνδυ τῆς πτώσεως.

msItem.title: Epistle 7 (Gautier)
msItem.rubric: f. 3v l. 16 Τῷ διδασκάλῳ τῆς μεγάλης ἐκκλησίας κυρῷ Νικήτᾳ, τῷ τοῦ Σερρῶν
msItem.incipit: f. 3v Ἐβουλόμην μὲν καὶ πρὸς τὴν σὴν ἱερότητα
msItem.explicit: f. 4v l. 4 καὶ βραχέων σου ῥημάτων ἀκούσεται.

msItem.title: Epistle 9 (Gautier)
msItem.incipit: f. 4v Δέσποτά μου ἅγιε, τοῖς πρότερον παρὰ τῆς βασιλείας σου
msItem.explicit: f. 5r l. 5 μᾶλλον δὲ ἀπειροπλάσιον τοῖς φιλοτιμήμασι.

msItem.title: Epistle 10 (Gautier)
msItem.rubric: f. 5r l. 6 Τῷ υἱῷ τοῦ σεβαστοκράτορος
msItem.incipit: f. 5r Εὐλογητὸς ὁ Θεὸς ὁ δοὺς ἡμῖν
msItem.explicit: f. 5r l. 25 τῷ ὕψει σου ἀντιλαμβανόμενον.

msItem.title: Epistle 11 (Gautier)
msItem.rubric: f. 5r l. 25 Τῷ σεβαστῷ κυρῷ Ἰωάννῃ, τῷ υἱῷ τοῦ σεβαστοκράτορος
msItem.incipit: f. 5r Ἐπειδὴ Θεὸς τοῖς πτωχοῖς τοῦ τοῖς μέρεσι
msItem.explicit: f. 6r l. 2 πάσης κακίας ἀνώτερον καὶ κακώσεως.

msItem.title: Epistle 12 (Gautier)
msItem.incipit: f. 6r Τῶν θείων ἀνδρῶν πανσέβαστέ μου αὐθέντα

msItem.title: Epistle 13 (Gautier)
msItem.rubric: f. 6v l. 6 Τῷ καίσαρι τῷ Μελισσηνῷ
msItem.incipit: f. 6v Δέσποτά μου ἅγιε τῇ βαρβάρῳ

msItem.title: Epistle 16 (Gautier)
msItem.explicit: f. 8v l. 2 ὡς ὁ μέγας ἀπόστολος ἐνετείλατο.

msItem.title: Epistle 17 (Gautier)
msItem.rubric: f. 8v l. 3 Τῷ γυναικαδέλφῳ τοῦ βασιλέως, κυρῷ Ἰωάννῃ
msItem.incipit: f. 8v Νῦν ἔγνωμεν, οἷον ἥλιον ἔχοντες κατεμύομεν

msItem.title: Epistle 18 (Gautier)
msItem.rubric: f. 9r l. 9 Τῷ Ταρωνειτοπούλῳ τῷ δουκὶ Σκοπίων
msItem.note: The text ends abruptly, incomplete, at P. Gautier, Theophylacte d'Achrida. Lettres (Thessalonica, 1986), pp. 137-597: ep. 18 l. 40; the scribe indicated this writing λείπει ("missing") in the left margin, and leaving the rest of the page and ff. 10r-10v blank

msItem.title: Epistle 22 (Gautier)
msItem.explicit: f. 11v l. 3 μιμητήν σε ποιῶν ἀκριβέστατον.
msItem.note: The text begins incomplete, at Gautier 1986, ep. 22 l. 11

msItem.title: Epistle 25 (Gautier)
msItem.incipit: f. 12r Ἑορτή μοι τὰ πρὸς σὲ γράμματα
msItem.explicit: f. 12v l. 9 τῷ πνεύματι αὐτοῦ τῷ ἀγαθῷ ὁδηγῶν.

msItem.title: Epistle 26 (Gautier)
msItem.rubric: f. 12v l. 9 Τῷ σεβαστῷ, τῷ υἱῷ τοῦ σεβαστοκράτορος
msItem.incipit: f. 12v Ἐγὼ δὲ καὶ ἄλλοις μεσιτεύειν

msItem.title: Epistle 27 (Gautier)
msItem.explicit: f. 13v l. 7 κακίας τε καὶ κακώσεως.

msItem.title: Epistle 75 (Gautier)
msItem.explicit: f. 14v l. 9 πανίερε καὶ ἅγιε δέσποτα.

msItem.title: Epistle 29 (Gautier)
msItem.incipit: f. 14v Οὔ τις τοι θεός εἰμι

msItem.title: Epistle 30 (Gautier)
msItem.rubric: f. 15r l. 15 Τῷ χαρτοφύλακι κυρῷ Νικηφόρῳ

msItem.title: Epistle 32 (Gautier)
msItem.explicit: f. 16v l. 22 πάσης κακίας ἀνώτερον καὶ κακώσεως.

msItem.title: Epistle 33 (Gautier)
msItem.explicit: f. 17r l. 8 τὸ πᾶν ἔχω τοῦ ᾄσματος.

msItem.title: Epistle 35 (Gautier)
msItem.rubric: f. 17v l. 1 Τῷ μητροπολίτῃ Ναυπάκτου, τῷ Χρυσοβέργῃ
msItem.incipit: f. 17v Διήλθομεν διὰ πυρὸς καὶ ὕδατος

msItem.title: Epistle 37 (Gautier)
msItem.rubric: f. 18v l. 21 Τῷ ἡγουμένῳ τῆς ἐν τῷ Ἀνάπλῳ μονῆς κυρῷ Συμεών
msItem.incipit: f. 18v Καὶ πῶς ἂν τὸν παρόντα
msItem.explicit: f. 19v l. 16 τῶν ἁγίων ἐν φωτί.

msItem.title: Epistle 38 (Gautier)
msItem.rubric: f. 19v l. 16 Τῷ Καματηρῷ κυρῷ Γρηγορίῳ

msItem.title: Epistle 39 (Gautier)
msItem.rubric: f. 20r l. 21 Τῷ κυρῷ Μιχαὴλ τῷ Παντεχνῇ

msItem.title: Epistle 40 (Gautier)
msItem.rubric: f. 21r l. 9 Τῷ κυρῷ Νικήτᾳ τῷ Πολίτῃ

msItem.title: Epistle 43 (Gautier)
msItem.incipit: f. 22r Ἀεί μοι τὸν πόθον ἀνάπτεις
msItem.explicit: f. 22v l. 4 πάσης κακύνσεως ἀνώτερος καὶ κακώσεως.

msItem.title: Epistle 44 (Gautier)
msItem.incipit: f. 22v Εἰ ὁ θεὸς ἀγάπη ἐστίν

msItem.title: Epistle 47 (Gautier)
msItem.incipit: f. 25r Περὶ ἐμοῦ δ’ οὐδεὶς λόγος

msItem.title: Epistle 48 (Gautier)
msItem.rubric: f. 25r l. 21 Τῷ κυρῶ Μιχαὴλ τῷ Παντεχνῇ
msItem.incipit: f. 25r Ἐρωτᾶς πῶς ἔχει τὰ ἡμέτερα
msItem.explicit: f. 25v l. 11 τὴν ἐν πᾶσιν ἱλαρωτέροις ἀνάπαυσιν.

msItem.title: Epistle 49 (Gautier)
msItem.rubric: f. 25v l. 11 Τῷ Σερβλίᾳ κυρῷ Ἰωάννῃ

msItem.title: Epistle 51 (Gautier)
msItem.rubric: f. 26r l. 6 Τῷ χαρτοφύλακι κυρῷ Νικηφόρῳ

msItem.rubric: f. 26v l. 27 Τῷ Καματηρῷ κυρῷ Γρηγορίῳ
msItem.incipit: f. 26v Καιρός μοι τὸ προφητικὸν εἰπεῖν

msItem.title: Epistle 55 (Gautier)
msItem.incipit: f. 29r Πάλαι τὴν ἐμαυτοῦ θρηνῶν τύχην

msItem.title: Epistle 56 (Gautier)
msItem.incipit: f. 30v Προσαγορεύω σε τὴν φίλην ἐμοὶ κεφαλήν

msItem.title: Epistle 72 (Gautier)

msItem.explicit: f. 31r l. 14 οὐ μικρὸν ἀποίσει τὸ ὄφελος.

msItem.title: Epistle 57 (Gautier)
msItem.incipit: f. 31r Λυπηρὰ μὲν τὰ κατὰ σέ

msItem.title: Epistle 74 (Gautier)
msItem.incipit: f. 31r Κ καί κεν τὸ βουλοίμην

msItem.title: Epistle 58 (Gautier)

msItem.explicit: f. 34r l. 24 μετὰ τοῦ πνεύματός σου.

msItem.title: Epistle 59 (Gautier)
msItem.rubric: f. 34r l. 25 Τῷ αὐτῷ ἀπὸ τῆς συνόδου παραιτησαμένῳ τὴν συνέλευσιν

msItem.title: Epistle 60 (Gautier)
msItem.rubric: f. 35v l. 26 Τῷ αὐτῷ παρὰ τοῦ ἀρχιεπισκόπου
msItem.incipit: f. 35v Ὅσα μὲν ἐπὶ τῇ τοῦ σοῦ γράμματος

msItem.title: Epistle 79 (Gautier)
msItem.incipit: f. 37v Ἐγὼ δὲ καὶ νεκρὸς ἤδη γενόμενος

msItem.title: Epistle 80 (Gautier)
msItem.rubric: f. 38v l. 24 Τῷ σεβαστῷ τῷ Πακουριανῷ κυρῷ Νικολάω
msItem.explicit: f. 39r l. 18 κακύνσεως ἀνώτερος καὶ κακώσεως.

msItem.title: Epistle 80 (Gautier)
msItem.incipit: f. 39r Καὶ πόθεν ἂν καὶ ποίας
msItem.note: The title given in the manuscript to the letter implies that it was addressed to the sebastos Pakourianos, however, this letter was addressed to Gregorios Taronites, see Gautier 1986, pp. 426-433
The text ends abruptly at Gautier 1986, p. 431 l. 61; the rest of f. 40r and f. 40v are blank

support.material:
Western paper, folded in folio. Watermarks: ff. 1-8 Ladder in a cartouche, surmounted by a Latin cross ( 87 37 ) in the centre of the leaf, very similar to Sosower Échelle 12 , which is dated to c. 1548 (probably in Rome).
ff. 9-40 Three flowers in a circle, surmounted by a 4-point star ( 70 43 ) in the centre of the leaf, identical with Sosower Fleur 8 , which is dated to c. 1542 (probably in Venice).

collation.p: Part I is formed by 5 quaternions; since the quires are sewn very tightly and there is no numbering, the structure has been reconstructed on the basis of the watermarks' position.

condition.p: Ink stains through: see, for example, ff. 5r, 21v.

handNote.p: ff. 1r-40r Hand A: the text has been written by Manuel Provataris (active 1546-1570) Provatarēs, Manouēl active 1546-1570 (Μανουὴλ Προβατάρης; on him see RGK I, 254, II 350, III 418). Among the characteristic forms of Provataris' script can be recognized: the ligature of final sigma with the circumflex, the ligature delta-iota-alfa/omicron with a long iota which is linked with the lower part of the next letter Period 2a
The text is written in dark brown ink; titles and initials in red.
There are corrections to the text by the scribe, in the margins.

decoDesc.decoNote: On f. 1r there is a frieze in red ink with a vine-scrolls motif. Similar friezes are found in manuscripts copied by Provataris, see e.g. MSS Città del Vaticano, Biblioteca Apostolica Vaticana, Barb. gr. 568 (see P. Canart, 'Les manuscrits copiés par Emmanuel Provataris (1546-1570 environ): Essai d'étude codicologique', in Mélanges Eugène Tisserant, VI (Città del Vaticano, 1964), pp. 173-287: Pl. 4) and Vat. gr. 1177 ( Canart (1964), Pl. 5).
Initials in red ink, in ekthesis with a simple vegetal decoration (see e.g. f. 1r).
Thick minor initials in red-ink, see e.g. f. 3r.

history.origin:
This part of the manuscript was copied by Manuel Provataris, who was active in Italy, around the
middle of the 16th century, a period consistent with the date suggested by the watermarks. Beside the script, other elements recurring in manuscripts copied by Provataris contribute to the identification of this scribe, such as the decoration (the frieze), and the watermarks (see P. Canart, 'Les manuscrits copiés par Emmanuel Provataris (1546-1570 environ): Essai d'étude codicologique', in Mélanges Eugène Tisserant, VI (Città del Vaticano, 1964), pp. 173-287: watermarks no. 21 and 32). In particular, both watermarks are present in Città del Vaticano, Biblioteca Apostolica Vaticana, gr. 1184, copied by Provataris in 1546 (see Canart (1964), pp. 265 tab. 1 and p. 252 no. 82), and in Città del Vaticano, Biblioteca Apostolica Vaticana, gr. 625, copied by Provataris in the years 1549-1550 (see Canart (1964), pp. 264 tab. i and p. 248 no. 65), and were used in the years 1546-1554 (see Canart (1964), p. 272, tab. iv). Therefore, this part of the manuscript could probably be dated more precisely to these years.

msItem.title: Church History, books 1-2
Historia Ecclesiastica, 1-2
msItem.rubric: f. 41r Σύνταγμα τῶν κατὰ τὴν ἐν Νικαίᾳ ἁγίαν σύνοδον πραχθέντων
msItem.incipit: f. 41r Τὰ κατὰ τὴν ἁγίαν καὶ μεγάλην καὶ οἰκουμενικὴν τῶν ἐπισκόπων
msItem.explicit: f. 143r ὁ θεός σε διαφυλάξει ἀδελφὲ ἀγαπητέ.
msItem.note:
This anonymous text has been traditionally attributed to
Gelasius of Cyzicus (5th century) Gelasius, of Cyzicus, active 475 (see G.C. Hansen, Anonyme Kirchengeschichte (Gelasius Cyzicenus, CPG 6034), (Berlin, 2002), pp. IX-XII)
As in the case of most of the manuscripts of this text, only books 1-2 and three letters by emperor Constantine are preserved (on this see Hansen (2002), pp. XII-XIII)

msItem.author: Constantine I
msItem.title: Epistle to Arius and the Arians
msItem.note: Also edited in: H.-G. Opitz, Athanasius Alexandrinus, Werke, Band III, Teil 1: Urkunden zur Geschichte des arianischen Streites 318-328, Lieferung 2: Kaiser Konstantins Schreiben zur Einberufung der nicänischen Synode - Brief Kaiser Konstantins an Arius und Genossen (Berlin, 1934) (repr. Berlin-Boston, 2012), Urkunde 34

msItem.author: Constantine I
msItem.title: Epistle to the church of Nikomedeia
msItem.note: Also edited in: Opitz (1934) (repr. Berlin-Boston, 2012), Urkunde 27

msItem.author: Constantine I
msItem.title: Epistle to bishop Theodotos of Laodikeia
msItem.note: Also edited in: Opitz (1934) (repr. Berlin-Boston, 2012), Urkunde 28

support.material: ff. 41-144 Western paper, folded in folio. No watermarks.

handNote.p: ff. 41r-143r Hand B: texts in part II have been all written by the same hand, in a minuscule script, vertical, showing a few ligatures. This hand has been identified in various manuscripts now in the Bayerische Staatsbibliothek in Munich, and has been called Main 5 Mon. 27 in B. Mondrain, 'Copistes et collectionneurs de manuscrits grecs au milieu du XVIe siècle: le cas de Johann Jakob Fugger d’Augsbourg', in Byzantinische Zeitschrift 84-85, no. 2 (1992), pp. 354-390. See, for example, ff. 357-398 in Mon. Cod. Graec. 45 .
The text is written in brown ink, titles and initials in red.

Hand a: another hand wrote corrections and additions in the margins, throughout, in a minuscule script datable to the 16th or early 17th century: see, for example, ff. 63v-64r, 134r. Perhaps by the same hand are a few notes in Latin on ff. 50v, 63v, 124v, citing a codex of Athanasius.
The text is written in a grey ink.

decoDesc.decoNote: Small crosses and undulating strokes are used as line fillers for the titles, see e.g. ff. 41r, 45v .
Thick minor initials in red-ink, see e.g. f. 41r.

history.origin: This part of the manuscript was copied by an anonymous scribe, identified as the so-called Main 5 Mon. 27, whose actvities have been dated around 1550 (see Mondrain (1992) and, among others, V. Tiftixoglu, Katalog der griechischen Handschriften der Bayerischen Staatsbibliothek München, 1: Codices graeci Monacenses 1 - 55 (Munich, 2004), pp. 262-271).
